So I realized -- technically, we already store this -- it's the write timestamp for the piece of metadata. But maybe actually *getting at* that is (and should be) outside of the scope of this bug.

Plus it lets us set up tests at least slightly more easily ;-)
Oh hey -- acoles had the same idea! https://review.opendev.org/#/c/569832/
Is this mainly for corrupted (but non-empty) values getting passed to json.loads(), or is there something else I'm not thinking of?

This API feels slightly backwards to me -- like, the context got loaded/created within the context of a broker, so the fact that we have to pass a broker in here... idk, it feels a little goofy.

But w/e, bug is buggy, and this fixes it. Swift gets better.
Y'know, I take it back -- we're just matching precedent with the store() API here.
so delete doesn't actually reap anything?  does reap now require this sysmeta?

Yeah, as long as the value is blank (or, technically, false-y) it'll get dropped from the response and not count against max_meta_count, right? https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.22.0/swift/container/server.py#L710

In the meantime, we want to make sure the removal gets replicated out, right?

Yeah, the reclaim_metadata (https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/db.py#L986) will go reap old metadata that has a value of "".

I didn't want to go reach and fiddle with the container metadata internals.

In a normal case, I think this is enough. At least it's marked to be deleted. Although doesn't speed up deleting if there are thousands of entries. Although, I hope that the fact that the value is '' they'll be skipped as that is suppose to mean they've been marked as deleted.
what's the cardinality here?  10's 1000's?  MILLIONS!?
In the steady-state after a fix, replica_count. While cleaning up from old, bug-ridden Swift, we've seen containers hit some 1200, 1300 total entries, which is ~10x the defaul max_meta_count.

To be honest, I'd expect it to be < 10's. The bug in question is interesting, as they would've had a slow or error limitted root container, so new empty containers might have been created on handoffs.. which then failed to shard fast enough (because currently we don't skip empty shard ranges). Leading to more and more CleaveContexts.

So we know NM had _alot_.

In general, I'd expect the number to generally be number of primaries in a perfect world. Plus some for rebalances and/or handoffs if that happens during sharding... so worse on large containers I suspect.

A cleavecontext uses the db ID as a reference, to keep track of that sharding. That only changes on handoffs, rebalances or maybe rsync+merge if I remember correctly.
nit: This could get hoisted up & out of the for-loop
Right, so here's our migration to add a last_modified if it doesn't already exist...
is this *only* to catch the old stuff - going forward do we mostly expect it should more or less always get caught when it finishes?

exactly, this is just for garbage collection. When a db enters SHARDING state it should be deleted. When the skip empty shards patch lands. I hope that sharding empty containers will shard quickly and therefore deleted quickly... so hopefully garbage collection becomes less and less.

Also worth noting: the penalty for accidentally deleting a context that shouldn't have been deleted is reasonably low. We won't lose data, but we can reset cleaving progress. As long as you configure reclaim_age higher than your sharder cycle times, you should be fine.

Note that even after this fix, there's a chance for this path to get triggered -- for example, if the sharder process crashes between unlinking the old DB and clearing the sysmeta.
and we call this regardless of shard/root status - because shard can cleave sometimes?
yeah, a root obviously cleave.. but so should shards when they get too big. So I assume we should garbage collect everywhere.
so this is a proactive delete going forward?

Yeah.

I figure, currently we don't seem to clean them up. When shards cleave, they can delete themselves. But I think these CleaveContexts stick around.. forever.. in the root. We could not proactive delete and let the garbage collecting do that job. Or we can be proactive, because we just unlinked the retiring DB here. As far as this particular DB is concerned it's done and wont need its context anymore.

But happy either way.

Let's remove mention of Pike so that no on is confused.

Just say the earliest OpenStack:Ceph version combo that we intend to support.

From this paragraph statement it seems there will be only 1 ganesha gateway for the system, could you please clarify?

If yes, all tenants will need to be connected to this single shared network through a single router, or the tenant's router will need to have an interface connected to the shared network. Could you please specify if it is one or the other? Also, there are additional security implications (please see my comment in security section)

If not, then if we don't create ganhesha server and leave it to the administrator to create (as it is expected in Manila DHSS=False drivers), then the administrator may be able to set up 1 ganesha server per tenant, with an interface on the tenant network, and map it to share type. Therefore there is no additional security concerns here, but our charm set up is not automated. I don't think there is a way for the charm to be automated in this case as it cannot set up individual servers appropriate for each tenant in the cloud.

Following up on this question - what are the access controls provides for access for a specific tenant to the NFS share? If its CIDR + username/password then that might be sufficient for this use case and is in some ways no worse that providing access to a NetApp filer over NFS.

Creating a Ganesha server per tenant seems expensive and something that end users of the charms would be reticent to do.
I just realized PCaaS is ambiguous. I meant Private Cloud as a Service.

to access a specific NFS share, it is necessary to provide the individual IP of the resource trying to mount the share, or the CIDR of its network to allow bulk access.

I am unaware of username/password being used for NFS while using Ganesha (I am not sure of its integrating capabilities with Kerberos/etc)

For the use case of a private company cloud where its a controlled environment that tenants trust each other I think that would be okay. But if the use case is Public Cloud or PCaaS, then, as I have witnessed in several manila discussions, there may be network security concerns w.r.t several different tenants accessing the same network port, even if one cannot mount the other's share. The concerns relate mostly to network spoofing, and I personally do not have experience with mechanisms to solve those concerns using Neutron (like security group stuff).

For example, what NetApp storage does to counter that, is to create a vlan in the physical storage interface for each tenant. This way, even if tenants are accessing the same physical port, they are doing through different vlans and traffic cannot be spoofed.

Something similar could be done for a single ganesha server, but being an OpenStack resource (a VM I suppose) it will be tied to a network and I don't think it would be able to have multiple vlans associated with it, unless you add a new port in the VM for each tenant tenant network in order to provide isolation.

If there is going to be a single ganesha server managed by the charm, perhaps we could add a charm action to add those ports based on parameters, so the administrator would have to just invoke the action and have less effort. In my personal experience I have never seen charms handling OpenStack resources (require admin credentials), but if that is ok and has been done before then perhaps this is a valid idea (otherwise how are you going to have the charm set up the single ganesha server?)

Btw, I heard there is active development on a Ceph-Ganesha DHSS=True driver that would solve all those concerns in the driver level, so perhaps if there is nothing else can improve on, then we could go with a single ganesha VM (connected through a tenant's router or public router, waiting for a response on that) but making sure we communicate that there are some limitations on the current architecture state given that the manila cephNFS driver with ganesha is only configurable in DHSS=False mode.

tripleo_ansible/roles/backup-and-restore.message: It'd be nice to add a comment here that indicates this hash requires strings to be single then double quoted because it will be used in configuration file which is interpreted by BASH.

I think you can delegate this task to the actual template. i.e. as we do it here:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/backup-and-restore/templates/local.conf.j2#L19

The thing is how can we make sure, we don't have colliding config parameters?

An example of this can be if you allow the parameter BACKUP: NETFS to be different, it will collide with i.e. OUTPUT_URL=nfs:// as it might not be NFS.

I think this change is something good to have, but I personally vote to move them all (not only the extra parameters) to avoid this possible parameters incompatibility.

WDYT to add to your default variable all the config parameters and then use some Jinja kung-fu to create the file based on the content of tripleo_backup_and_restore_extra_local_config ? In which case I would rename it as tripleo_backup_and_restore_config_local

  tripleo_backup_and_restore_config_exports
  tripleo_backup_and_restore_config_rescue

What is the root cause of the bug?

Or does it happen when 'name' field does not exist?

It is unclear to me to determine the change is appropriate.

magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernet.message: Alternative: set CLOUD_PROVIDER_ENABLED to False when trust is disabled.

Is it a misconfiguration to have CLOUD_PROVIDER_ENABLED without trust enabled?

I'm just thinking if the user has asked for a cloud provider but we cannot do it due to trusts, we could catch that case and provide an error?
CLOUD_PROVIDER_ENABLED is true by default. Its only when cluster_user_trust is True that CLOUD_PROVIDER_ENABLED becomes usable.
That is an edge case which would lead to problems. Probably a good idea to catch it and fail early before the cluster even gets created.

CLOUD_PROVIDER_ENABLED flag is passed in using labels, TRUST_ID comes in when cluster_user_trust=True. At the moment, /etc/sysconfig/heat-params has a snapshot of all the cluster params. The danger with overriding CLOUD_PROVIDER_ENABLED is that it may make things more difficult to debug but happy to hear what others too have to say on the matter.
Yes, I agree with you, makes the TRUST_ID check redundant.

We fall back to the previous behavior. The addition of the 'pcpuset' field allows us to track host CPUs intended for dedicated (pinned) instances separately, leaving 'cpuset' to track only the host CPUs intended for for non-dedicated instances. Before we added this, 'cpuset' was used for both, and by setting 'pcpuset' to the value of 'cpuset', we essentially continue with that previous behavior. The alternative to this is to update the individual references to 'pcpuset' (e.g. [1]) to do the fallback there instead, but I think explicitly handling things in the places where we expect to receive older object versions as we've done here is a better idea.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671800/30/nova/objects/numa.py@80

I do, because of the ordering of how we call these. L1111 handles things for 'numa_fit_instance_to_host' <A> while this handles things for 'numa_usage_from_instance_numa' <B>. In 'nova/scheduler/host_manager.py', we call <A> first followed by <B> [1]. However, in 'nova/compute/resource_tracker.py' we call <B> without calling <A> [2]. As such, both <A> and <B> need to handle these older object versions.

An alternative would be to provide a helper function on the 'ComputeNode' object that deserializes the 'numa_topology' field and sets 'pcpuset' if it's not set and then replace [3] and [4] with a call to that helper. However, that further abstracts things so I'm not sure I want to do that.

Not really related to the patch, but can you please explain this assertion to me?

I take it this is not the same as saying it's dumb to have both dedicated and shared instances on the same host. Otherwise we should be hatin on cpu_dedicated_set and cpu_shared_set being configured on the same host, which (afaik??) we're not doing.

So pinned/unpinned must be orthogonal to shared/dedicated. If so, what does pinned+shared mean? That my VM is still restricted to using CPUs x, y, and z, but it's also possible for *other* VMs to be sharing x, y, and/or z?

If I'm logicking right so far, then I still don't get why it should be dumb to have pinned and unpinned on the same host. It makes sense to me to have the cpu_dedicated_set be used for pinned instances and have the procs in cpu_shared_set float freely across any/all unpinned instances as needed. Or even within cpu_shared_set to have one or more VMs pinned to x, y, and z while others float over a, b, and c.

So what am I missing?

I'm talking about the situation as it currently exists, and which this series is intended to resolve. If you boot a pinned instances alongside an unpinned instances, each core of the former will be pinned to a specific host cores, while each core of the latter will be "pinned" to the whole range of host cores (or all those from a single host NUMA node, if the unpinned instance happens to have a NUMA topology). This means the pinned instances don't get the guarantees that no one else is using those CPUs that were expected. With this series, we're separating out these two instance types such that they all have their own dedicated range of cores that means overlap just isn't possible

Ah, so it was only "dumb" if the operator was aware of this:

 > pinned to a specific host cores, while each core of the latter will
 > be "pinned" to the whole range of host cores (or all those from a
 > single host NUMA node, if the unpinned instance happens to have a
 > NUMA topology). This means the pinned instances don't get the
 > guarantees that no one else is using those CPUs that were expected.

Otherwise it was just them incorrectly (but not unreasonably) assuming a certain behavior.
it's an upgrade impact then, you should at least document this in a release note IIUC.

I think I wasn't clear. I'm saying this is what _could_ happen if I didn't do this thing. However, this patch adds checks to prevent this happening. With this change, if a user only sets 'cpu_dedicated_set' but there are unpinned instances on the host, we will error out. Similarly, if a user only sets 'cpu_shared_set' but there are pinned instances on the host, we will error out. Finally, if a user sets either 'vcpu_pin_set' or 'cpu_dedicated_set' and the pinned cores are out of range, we log a warning. The reason we can error out for the first two cases is because these are new options and therefore we don't need to worry about existing broken deployments. For the latter, we have to worry about the bug that artom is trying to fix resulting in pinned CPUs being wrong.

cyborg/accelerator/drivers/fpga/intel/sy.message:
Throughout the code, I see this mixup of PFs, VFs and devices. We can say, at least for now, that a PF corresponds to a device. However, a VF is an attach handle that is associated with a deployable, not a device.

More below.

it is not a mixup, the "device_name" here is not same as "device" definition in cyborg DB. It is a definition in driver level, from driver's point of view, a device could be PF or VF, e.g. "intel-fpga-dev.*" . Besides there is a parameter vf indicating whether the device is a VF or not. 
If this confused you, what kind of name you think is better? I am willing to change.

This still does not get the region IDs in OPAE 1.0.*. Try this diff:
diff --git a/cyborg/accelerator/drivers/fpga/intel/sysinfo.py b/cyborg/accelerator/drivers/fpga/intel/sysinfo.py
index 6afcfab..16d0337 100644
--- a/cyborg/accelerator/drivers/fpga/intel/sysinfo.py
+++ b/cyborg/accelerator/drivers/fpga/intel/sysinfo.py
@@ -175,8 +175,8 @@ def get_region_ids(device_name):
         read_line,
         glob.glob(
             os.path.join(
-                SYS_FPGA, device_name, "device/physfn/fpga",
-                "intel-fpga-dev.*", "intel-fpga-fme.*", "pr/interface_id")
+                SYS_FPGA, device_name,
+                "intel-fpga-fme.*", "pr/interface_id")
         )
     )


Given a PF, we can get a region ID from:
    /sys/class/fpga/intel-fpga-dev.0/intel-fpga-fme.0/pr/interface_id

Since the pr/interface_id (region id) is under FME, which is part of the blue bits, it is best read from PF.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
Emm...this changed existing vcpu_pin_set behavior. 

For dedicated instance host, the offline cpu won't work. For the shared instance host, this change will shrink the number of available vcpus.

i personally would prefer to only report online cpus too.

that said i would also prefer to require the cpu_dedicated_set and cpu_shared_set options to be set in U

i.e. have no option to not set at least one of them.

at a minium i would like to enforce that for the libvirt driver.

i was aware that we only check online cpus if vcpu_pin_set was defeiend but it always felt like a bug that we did not check when it was not set.

this is one of the reasons why i have always advised useing vcpu_pin_set even if you dont care about numa or other high performance usecases. the other is to properly be able to reserve specific cores for the host to use.
Emm..I agree with you guys, it is a bug. I also think this is corner cases. So i'm ok with this.

So yes, there is a change in behavior here if none of CONF.vcpu_pin_set, CONF.compute.cpu_shared_set or CONF.compute.cpu_dedicated_set are set. Before this change, we would fall back to reporting *all* CPUs on the host for VCPU inventory, whether they were online or offline. After this change, we will only report online CPUs. Is that what you're referring to? If so, this was a conscious decision on my behalf. It felt like a bug to report CPUs as usable when we were not able to actually use them. For non-NUMA instances, this would result in a higher overcommit ratio than expected, while for non-NUMA instances, the NUMATopology filter would error out more frequently because there would be a mismatch between the number of cores the host NUMATopology object was saying was available vs. what was being reported in placement (see [1]).

I can revert this but I don't think that's wise. Perhaps I could split this out into a separate patch (possibly with a bug against it) or add a note in the commit message explaining the above. With that said though, I suspect the reason nobody has seen this issue is because the values from the libvirt 'getCPUMap' function (returned by 'nova.virt.libvirt.Host.get_online_cpus') and third item of the 'getInfo' function (returned by 'nova.virt.libvirt.Host.get_cpu_count') very rarely differ is because most people aren't disabling CPUs on their platform and therefore aren't running into these corner cases

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/eb6fcb21917d56e4e287513c1159ad4656382714/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L6555-L6560

octavia/certificates/common/local.py.message:
The fernet documentation describes this key as "A URL-safe base64-encoded 32-byte key."
Why don't you add a "regex" and "max_length" to this StrOpt that validates for that criteria?
As a (not correct) example: ^[a-zA-Z]{32}$ would match a string of letters exactly 32 characters long.
Does the pass phrase need to be 32 characters log or the final base64 encoded string?
